item.title: 2024 rewind: Major news events as seen from space - India Today
item.description:
2024 Rewind: Major News Events as Seen from Space

Publication Date: Dec 30, 2024 Source: India Today

As 2024 draws to a close, India Today looks back at the highlights and lowlights of the jam-packed year as seen from space, encompassing domestic and global events.

  • January: Inauguration of Ram Temple in Ayodhya capturing millions' attention.
  • February: Violent protests in Sandeshkhali, West Bengal linked to land grabs and abuse allegations.
  • March: Cargo vessel Dali collided with Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore.
  • April: Severe forest fires in Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh resulted in multiple deaths.
  • June: Construction of a humanitarian aid pier in Gaza, critical amidst ongoing conflict.
  • July: Devastating landslides in Wayanad, Kerala, leading to many fatalities.
  • August: The 2024 Summer Olympics held in Paris, capturing iconic landmarks from space.
  • September: Floods in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana killed numerous individuals, analyzed through satellite data.
  • October: New patrolling arrangement announced between India and China post-border tensions.
  • November: Delay in snowfall at Mount Fuji noted, raising environmental concerns.
  • December: Collapse of Assad's regime in Syria as rebel forces took control of Damascus.
"The initial snowfall on the UNESCO World Heritage site was visible from the southwestern side of the mountain. The absence of snow on Mount Fuji on November 5 broke the previous record for the latest snowfall."

This year has been pivotal, marked by significant events captured from space, underlining the role of satellite technology in understanding global affairs.

item.title: NASA probe makes closest ever pass by the sun - The Hindu
item.description:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Closest Approach to the Sun

Published Date: December 30, 2024 - Source: The Hindu

NASA’s Parker Solar Probe made history on December 24 by flying closer to the sun than any other spacecraft, enduring scorching temperatures of over 930 degrees Celsius.

  • Launched in August 2018, the spacecraft is part of a seven-year mission.
  • The probe flew within 6.1 million kilometers of the sun.
  • Mission scientists expect confirmation of the flyby on December 28.
  • The Parker Solar Probe will encounter two more close passes in March and June 2025.
  • The craft can achieve speeds of around 690,000 km/h.
“Right now, the Parker Solar Probe is flying closer to a star than anything has ever been before.” - Nicky Fox, NASA official

This groundbreaking flyby is part of a series of missions aimed at understanding solar winds and the mysteries of the sun's atmosphere.

item.title: Year-ender | Top space exploration moments and discoveries of 2024 - CNBCTV18
item.description:
Top Space Exploration Moments and Discoveries of 2024

Date: December 31, 2024

Source: CNBC

In 2024, space exploration soared with historic lunar south pole samples, groundbreaking all-civilian spacewalks, and key milestones pushing the boundaries of human and robotic achievements.

  • Japan’s Moon Landing: In January, Japan landed its SLIM spacecraft on the moon, becoming the fifth country to do so.
  • First Private Spacecraft on the Moon: Intuitive Machines’ Odysseus landed in February, marking a milestone for private space exploration.
  • First Ever Moon Dust Samples: China’s Chang’e 6 mission returned unique samples from the moon's far side.
  • Ancient Microbial Life on Mars: NASA’s Perseverance rover in July found evidence suggesting ancient life on Mars.
  • First All-Civilian Spacewalk: SpaceX’s Polaris Dawn mission included a historic civilian spacewalk in September.
  • Astronauts Stuck in Space: Boeing’s Starliner had thruster issues, stranding astronauts until February 2025.
  • A Mission to Jupiter’s Icy Moon: NASA’s Europa Clipper embarked on a six-year journey to Jupiter in October.
“2024 was a pivotal year in space exploration.”

This recap illustrates the continuous advancements in space exploration, showcasing remarkable achievements and milestones reached in 2024.

item.title: Science News | ⚡Know Dates of Lunar Eclipse, Solar Eclipse Set To Occur in 2025 - LatestLY
item.description:
Eclipse Schedule for 2025: Lunar and Solar Eclipse Dates Revealed

Publication Date: --, Source: --

In 2025, four major eclipses are set to occur, including two solar and two lunar eclipses. India will witness a full lunar eclipse in September, along with other celestial events such as meteor showers and supermoons.

  1. Two solar eclipses
  2. Two lunar eclipses, including one visible in India
  3. Other celestial events like meteor showers and supermoons

item.title: 2 solar, lunar eclipses in 2025; India to witness only THIS eclipse - DNA India
item.description:
Four Eclipse Events in 2025; India Witnesses Final Lunar Eclipse

Date and Source:

Published: December 30, 2024 | Source: DNA

Image with Caption:

Introduction:

The year 2025 is set to be an exciting one for skywatchers, with no less than four eclipse events scheduled. However, Indians will have to wait until the final lunar eclipse to witness any of these celestial phenomena.

Key Points:

  1. The year begins with a full lunar eclipse on March 14, 2025, but unfortunately, it will not be visible from India.
  2. A second partial solar eclipse on March 29, 2025, will also pass over India.
  3. Indians will finally get to witness an eclipse on September 7-8, 2025, with a breathtaking full lunar eclipse visible from Asia, Europe, and the Indian Ocean region.
  4. The year concludes with a partial solar eclipse on September 21-22, visible only in regions such as New Zealand, the South Pacific, and West Antarctica.

Notable Quotes or Statistics:

The series of eclipses in 2025 will begin with a full lunar eclipse on March 14, 2025, but unfortunately, it will not be visible in India, according to Dr. Rajendra Prakash Gupt, Superintendent of the observatory. However, he noted that this celestial event will follow a second partial solar eclipse on March 29, 2025, which again India will miss out on. Indians, however, can look forward to the full lunar eclipse between September 7 and September 8, 2025, as the moon transforms into a deep crimson hue, lasting from 8:58 PM to 2:25 AM, according to Mr. Gupt.

Conclusion:

While Indians will have to wait for the final lunar eclipse in 2025 to witness any eclipse events, skywatchers around the world can look forward to a series of remarkable celestial phenomena in the coming year.

item.title: My fight with Claude on Big O notation O(1) Time Complexity | by Naveenkumar Murugan | Dec, 2024 - Medium
item.description:
My Fight with Claude on Big O Notation: Understanding O(1) Time Complexity

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Medium

This article explores the author's journey to simplify the concept of O(1) time complexity in algorithms, highlighting common confusions and aiming to provide a clearer understanding.

Key Points:

  • Attempts to provide a simpler definition of time complexity for better understanding.
  • Common definition of O(1) as time bounded by a finite value, regardless of input size.
  • Author shares personal confusions regarding the meaning of “1” in O(1).
  • Quotes important to the author, emphasizing clarity in explanation.
“If you can’t explain the thing to a 5 year old kid, you haven’t understood the thing enough.”

Conclusion:

The author encourages readers to rethink traditional definitions and digest complex concepts into simpler explanations.

item.title: 7 Latest Space Pictures Captured By NASA Hubble Space - Times Now
item.description:
7 Latest Space Pictures Captured By NASA Hubble Space

Publication Date: Dec 30, 2024 | Source: Times Now

This article features a stunning collection of the latest space pictures captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, showcasing various celestial phenomena.

  • The Mice NGC 4676: Colliding spiral galaxies indicating star formation.
  • Westerlund 2: A star cluster located in a stellar nursery.
  • Discovering Protostellar OH 339.88-1.26: A dusty area with bright stars.
  • Young Star HH-47: A complex stellar formation.
  • XZ Tauri: A multiple star system with gas expulsion.
  • Red Giant Star CW Leonis: A stunning carbon star image.
  • Ghostly Star Forming Pillar: The Cone Nebula captured in detail.
“NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope has captured an impressive image of the multiple star system known as XZ Tauri alongside neighbor HL Tauri and several young stellar objects.”

This article provides a glimpse into the wonders of space explored by the Hubble Space Telescope, highlighting remarkable cosmic phenomena.

item.title: The 10 most intriguing science breakthroughs of 2024 - The Times of India
item.description:
The 10 most intriguing science breakthroughs of 2024

Date: (Insert publication date here) Source: (Insert source here)

2024 was overshadowed by the turmoil surrounding the US election and ongoing wars, but significant discoveries were made in various scientific fields that could improve health and expand our understanding of the universe.

  • Moon Rocks from Terra Incognita: Chinese spacecraft Chang’e-6 returned with two kilograms of lunar rock from the far side of the Moon.
  • A Drug that Prevents HIV: Lenacapavir, a new drug for HIV prevention, showed 100% efficacy in clinical trials among 2,134 women and girls.
  • AI and Human Psyche: AI has begun helping social scientists understand human thought and debunk conspiracy theories effectively.
  • Europa Clipper Mission: NASA launched a mission aimed at exploring the potential for extraterrestrial life on Jupiter's moon Europa.
  • James Webb Telescope Insights: New measurements recalibrate the rate of the universe's expansion and unveil new galaxies.
  • Aging Research: Significant biological changes in individuals at ages 44 and 60 were revealed, affecting metabolism and health.
  • Earth's Climate Reconstruction: A comprehensive new study detailed Earth's fluctuating climate over the last 485 million years.
  • Microplastics Health Risks: Studies revealed the buildup of microplastics in human organs, linked to health risks.
  • Occupations and Longevity: Studies suggest that certain professions may help postpone mental decline and increase lifespan.
  • Quantum Computing Advances: Significant progress makes quantum computing closer to practical use, overcoming previous error challenges.
“I don’t like plastic, but I like the convenience of food and drinks in plastic packaging.”

The breakthroughs of 2024 illustrate a remarkable year in science, from healthcare advancements to profound insights about our universe, indicating both opportunities and challenges ahead.

item.title: NASA’s James Webb Telescope discovers life supporting gases on a planet in space - The Times of India
item.description:
NASA’s James Webb Telescope discovers life supporting gases on a planet in space

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

NASA’s James Webb Telescope has made a groundbreaking discovery of gases that may support life on a distant planet, indicating exciting possibilities for extraterrestrial life.

  • The James Webb Telescope detected atmospheric gases that could be signs of life.
  • This discovery is a significant advancement in the search for habitable planets.
  • The findings could reshape our understanding of where life could exist beyond Earth.
“This could be one of the biggest discoveries in the search for extraterrestrial life.”

This discovery opens new avenues in our quest to understand life in the universe, pushing the boundaries of what we know and exploring new worlds.

item.title: 7 RAREST pics of mysterious universe by NASA - India.com
item.description:
7 RAREST pics of mysterious universe by NASA

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: India.com

This article highlights seven rare photographs of the universe captured by NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope, showcasing the beauty and mystery of our cosmos.

  • Asteroid Dimorphos captured on December 19, 2022.
  • ‘Spoke Season’ on Saturn observed from approximately 850 million miles away.
  • Image of the bright spiral galaxy MCG-01-24-014, located about 275 million light-years away.
  • UGC 8091 showcasing billions of glittering stars, resembling a snow globe.
  • Spiral galaxy NGC 6951 featuring bright blue spiral arms.
  • Rare Radio Galaxy NGC 612 exhibiting vibrant orange and blue streaks.
  • G35.2-0.7N region captured in stunning detail.
“These images not only provide scientific insight but also inspire awe about the universe we live in.”

The article emphasizes the importance of such images in understanding the universe's vastness and complexities, revealing both scientific and artistic marvels.

item.title: The Kessler Syndrome: The doom scenario worrying scientists - The Jerusalem Post
item.description:
The Kessler Syndrome: The Doom Scenario Worrying Scientists

Publication Date: DECEMBER 30, 2024

Source: The Jerusalem Post

The Kessler Syndrome is a growing concern among scientists, predicting that an increase in satellites will lead to catastrophic collisions in space, rendering it unusable.

  • The US Space Command reported that the Intelsat 33e satellite broke apart into roughly 20 pieces, heightening worries about space debris.
  • Bill Therien of ExoAnalytic Solutions highlighted the challenges of tracking space debris, which ranges from small fragments to larger pieces.
  • The Kessler Syndrome, proposed in 1978, suggests that collisions in low Earth orbit will lead to further debris and collisions.
  • Over 10,000 active satellites currently orbit Earth, with significant contributions from companies like SpaceX's Starlink.
  • Experts call for international regulations to tackle the risks posed by space debris.
"If the probability of a collision is so great that we can't put a satellite in space, then we're in trouble," warned John L. Crassidis.

Experts emphasize the increasing urgency of establishing regulations to manage space debris and the need for cooperative global efforts.

item.title: NASA’s Breakthrough Discovery Explains Vesta’s Mysterious Gullies - SciTechDaily
item.description:
NASA’s Breakthrough Discovery Explains Vesta’s Mysterious Gullies

Publication Date: 21 October 2024  Source: The Planetary Science Journal

Scientists reveal that the mysterious gullies on asteroid Vesta may have formed through sudden brine flows triggered by meteoroid impacts, rather than dry debris flows.

  • The surfaces of celestial bodies, including Vesta, bear signs of ancient impacts.
  • New evidence points to short-lived water flows created by impacts as a potential source for the gullies.
  • Laboratory experiments simulate Vesta's conditions to explore how salty water flows could have shaped the surface.
  • Salt extends the fluid stability of brine, allowing it to flow long enough to create surface features.
  • NASA’s Dawn mission previously hinted at hidden subsurface ice on Vesta.
“Not only do impacts trigger a flow of liquid on the surface, the liquids are active long enough to create specific surface features.” - Jennifer Scully, NASA

This discovery enhances our understanding of surface processes on airless worlds and the role of brine in shaping landscapes in the solar system.

item.title: New Image Revealed by NASA of their New Martian Helicopter. - Universe Today
item.description:
NASA Unveils New Martian Helicopter Concept: Mars Chopper

Date: Not specified Source: NASA

NASA has released a computer rendering of their next design, the Mars Chopper, following the success of the Ingenuity helicopter. This next-generation vehicle promises improved capabilities for Martian aerial exploration.

  • Ingenuity was the first aircraft to fly on Mars, completing 60 flights since its first in April 2021.
  • The new Mars Chopper design features six rotors with higher payload capacity for scientific instruments.
  • This technology aims to enhance scouting, analysis, and support human exploration of Mars.
  • The challenges of Martian atmosphere, including low density and dust, were addressed in the new design.
“Ingenuity led the way proving the technology and now, with the new concept Mars Choppers on the drawing board, aerial reconnaissance on these new worlds will vastly improve the value of ground-based exploration.”

The Mars Chopper represents a significant advancement in aerial exploration technology for Mars and potentially other planetary bodies with atmospheres supportive of flight.

item.title: NASA Confirms: Parker Probe Survives 'Touching Sun' in Record-Breaking Flyby - ScienceAlert
item.description:
NASA Confirms: Parker Probe Survives 'Touching Sun' in Record-Breaking Flyby

Date: December 24th, 2024

Source: Universe Today

The Parker Solar Probe made its closest approach to the Sun, passing just 6 million km above the surface and achieving a velocity of about 692,000 km/h. NASA confirmed that the probe successfully transmitted a beacon tone after the flyby.

  • The Parker Probe broke the previous distance record set by Helios 2.
  • It became the fastest human-made object, reaching speeds of around 692,000 km/h.
  • It conducted science operations during close passes to enhance our understanding of solar wind origins.
  • Its journey began with gravity-assist maneuvers involving Venus.
  • The probe's carbon foam shield protects it from extreme temperatures in the solar corona.
"Flying this close to the Sun is a historic moment in humanity's first mission to a star..." - Nicky Fox, NASA Associate Administrator

The Parker Solar Probe continues to provide critical data that could transform our understanding of solar phenomena and their effects on space weather.

item.title: Karnal students recognised by NASA for asteroid discovery - The Tribune India
item.description:
Karnal Students Recognized by NASA for Asteroid Discovery

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Tribune

Twelve students and two teachers from Dyal Singh Public School have been recognized by NASA’s IASC for discovering a main belt asteroid, TD40, using data from the Pan-STARRS telescope.

This recognition awards the students for their scientific exploration and teamwork.

  • Twelve students and two teachers received recognition from NASA’s IASC.
  • The students discovered and registered 11 near-Earth objects.
  • Diksha, a Class XI student, discovered and registered a main belt asteroid.
  • A ceremony was held at the school to honor the students and teachers.
  • Principal Sushma Devgun emphasized the importance of this recognition for student motivation.
“This recognition has instilled a sense of pride and motivated students to explore new opportunities in science and education.” - Principal Sushma Devgun

This achievement highlights the potential of young students in contributing to scientific discovery and encourages further exploration in the field.

item.title: Remote sensing can help prevent plastic from reaching the ocean - Earth.com
item.description:
Remote sensing can help prevent plastic from reaching the ocean

Publication Date: Not specified; Source: Earth.com

Innovative research from the University of Minnesota focuses on utilizing remote sensing technology to monitor and remove plastic debris from rivers, addressing the significant issue of plastic pollution that often goes unrecognized in freshwater environments.

  • The study published in Nature highlights the contribution of rivers to oceanic plastic pollution.
  • Traditional methods of monitoring plastic are costly and time-consuming; remote sensing offers a more scalable solution.
  • Advanced technology can differentiate plastic from natural debris in freshwater environments.
  • The researchers aim to mitigate the problem at the source before plastics reach the oceans.
  • Future research plans include examining larger river systems and origins of plastic pollution.
“If we can develop technology at the Mississippi headwaters... we can protect the downstream states and the entire ocean from plastic pollution.” – Professor Ardeshir Ebtehaj

The study emphasizes early intervention in freshwater systems as crucial for managing plastic pollution effectively. Ongoing developments in this technology could significantly enhance efforts to protect ecosystems and the oceans.

item.title: Sun unleashes massive X1.1 solar flare to close out 2024 (photo) - Space.com
item.description:
Sun Unleashes X1.1 Solar Flare to End 2024

Date: December 29, 2024 | Source: Space.com

The sun has fired a powerful X1.1 solar flare, marking perhaps its last major flare of 2024. This event generated a strong radio blackout over parts of Earth and could amplify auroras as the year concludes.

  • The solar flare erupted from the northwest region of the sun at 2:18 a.m. EST (0718 GMT).
  • NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center reported a strong radio blackout due to the flare.
  • Officials are investigating if there was an associated coronal mass ejection (CME) that could impact Earth.
  • If a CME is confirmed, it may enhance New Year's auroras.
  • This X1.1 flare was not the largest of 2024; that title belongs to the X9 flare from October 3.
“Analysis is currently underway to determine if there was an associated coronal mass ejection, and any potential impacts,” SWPC officials stated.

While significant, the X1.1 flare adds to a year of remarkable solar activity, leaving watchers eager for what the new year may bring.

item.description:
10 Mesmerising Images of Galaxies by NASA

Date: Dec 29, 2024

Source: DNA

This article showcases stunning images of various galaxies captured by NASA, highlighting their unique features and cosmic beauty.

  • Caldwell 5 located in the Camelopardalis constellation.
  • The Pinwheel Galaxy, 21 million light-years away in Ursa Major.
  • Galaxy M94, 16 million light-years away in Canes Venatici.
  • NGC 6744 is a galaxy about 30 million light-years away in the Pavo constellation.
  • NGC 1448 features a supermassive black hole at its center.
  • The Antennae Galaxies are abundant with black holes and neutron stars.
  • This active barred spiral galaxy has experienced three supernovae since 1992.
  • The Needle Galaxy is featured among the captivating images.

Source: NASA

item.title: 555-million-year-old fossil bridges a gap in evolution - The Times of India
item.description:
555-Million-Year-Old Fossil Reveals Evolutionary Origins of Ecdysozoa

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Times of India

A groundbreaking fossil estimated to be 555 million years old has provided significant insights into the origins of Ecdysozoa, including insects and crustaceans. The discovery confirms their Precambrian roots and is pivotal in understanding the evolutionary history of this major animal group.

  • The fossil, named Uncus dzaugisi, is the oldest known member of the Ecdysozoa.
  • It was discovered in Nilpena Ediacara National Park, Australia, a site known for well-preserved Ediacaran lifeforms.
  • Researchers used hand tools meticulously to recover the fossil from fine-grained sandstone, which enhances detail preservation.
  • The discovery supports theories that Ecdysozoans predate the Cambrian explosion.
  • Ecdysozoans are among the largest and most diverse groups of animals on Earth, comprising a significant portion of the animal kingdom.
“Ecdysozoans were prevalent in the Cambrian fossil record... But, until now, we had no concrete fossil evidence to confirm it,” - Ian Hughes, lead author.

This finding highlights an important chapter in the evolutionary narrative, shedding light on the early presence of complex life forms prior to the Cambrian explosion.
